---
title: 'The US banking crisis in 2023: Intraday attention and price variation of banks
  at risk'
type: pub
encoding: UTF-8

---
<h1>Publication</h1>
<article id="csl-bib-container-SHFFMXPN" class="csl-bib-container">
  <div class="csl-bib-body"> <div class="csl-entry">Lyócsa, Š., Halousková, M., &#38; Haugom, E. (2023). The US banking crisis in 2023: Intraday attention and price variation of banks at risk. <i>Finance Research Letters</i>, <i>57</i>. <a href="https://doi.org/10.1016/j.frl.2023.104209">https://doi.org/10.1016/j.frl.2023.104209</a></div> </div>

<div id="csl-bib-meta-SHFFMXPN" class="csl-bib-meta">
  <article id="about-article-SHFFMXPN" class="about_pub-article">
    <h1>About</h1>
    Lyócsa et al. examined the US banking crisis in 2023, focusing on how interest rate hikes led to a drop in the value of long-term assets. This caused banks like Silicon Valley Bank and Signature Bank to face sudden, large withdrawals, resulting in their takeover by the FDIC. First Republic Bank was later acquired by JPMorgan Chase. The authors found that during the crisis, increased attention on Twitter was linked to greater price changes in banks at risk. This suggests that monitoring social media attention could help improve pricing strategies during financial crises. Their study highlights the importance of considering public attention in financial decision-making, especially in times of economic distress.
  </article>
  <article id="keywords-article-SHFFMXPN" class="keywords-article">
    <h1>Keywords</h1>
    US Banking Crisis, Interest Rate Hikes, Market Value, Deposit Withdrawals, Twitter-Based Attention, Price Variation
  </article>
  <article id="abstract-article-SHFFMXPN" class="abstract-article">
    <h1>Scientific abstract</h1>
    After interest rate hikes by the FED, the market value of long-duration assets has declined, which in March of 2023 led to a distress of banks subject to a sudden increase in deposit withdrawals. First, Silicon Valley Bank and Signature Bank were subject to such runs and were taken over by the FDIC, while First Republic Bank by JPMorgan Chase in May of 2023. We date the crisis-period and show that increased Twitter-based attention is related to an increased price variation of banks at risk. Our results imply that during crisis periods, pricing can be improved by incorporating attention-based measures.
  </article>
